Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Submicron Fracture Toughness Measurements for Cement Paste using Focused Ion Beam (FIB) and Nanoindentation

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Early-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) award is to measure the fracture toughness of cement paste at submicron length scales using nanoindentation experiments with Focused Ion Beam (FIB) milled sample structures. Modeling fracture and plastic failure of cement and concrete materials often involves introducing the concept of microcracks, which propagate and eventually coalesce to cause material failure at larger scales. The small scale of these cracks and the volumes around them pose many challenges for measurements and modeling. New experimental techniques are required to quantitatively assess the quasi-brittle failure mechanisms at small scales that govern microcracking and eventually material failure. Research tasks will begin with development of experimental methods to create sample micro-structures using FIB milling. Micropillars, notched beams, and wedge-splitting geometries are will be tried as alternatives. Next, these sample structures will be tested using nanoindentation equipment to apply loads and measure displacements. This data will be analyzed to deliver strength and fracture toughness properties. Finally, sample data will be collected to build a preliminary statistical model of measured properties, focusing on the ability to measure material properties that are repeatable within each phase but distinguishable between phases.

The production of cement generates between 3-5 percent of total carbon dioxide emissions worldwide, but this could be significantly reduced if concrete is engineered to be more resistant to quasi-brittle failure. Damage and failure of concrete is often modeled by invoking the existence of microcracks in cement paste, but the properties of these microcracks and the material behaviors that lead to microcracks are not well understood. Concrete damage from extreme loading conditions or from durability issues including alkali-silica reaction, freeze-thaw cycles, reinforcement corrosion, and delayed ettringite formation that lead to microcracking may be understood and prevented if the origins of microcracking are understood. New knowledge about the fundamental origins of failure behaviors of will enable rational design of modified and new materials that will lead to more efficient use of natural resources and more sustainable and resilient structures. The research in this project represents an important first step towards this overall goal, and will enable future research to more broadly characterize the failure behavior of cement and concrete at small length scales. The techniques developed will be applicable to a wide range of other materials, including sedimentary rocks such as shale and carbonates, and biological materials such as bones, teeth, and shells.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Concrete is the single most widely used material in the world. From tower blocks to carparks – this material is used so widely in construction industry that production, transportation, and use of concrete accounts for between 5-9% of total CO2 emissions worldwide. Cement, the key ingredient of concrete, is a nano-structured, multi-phase, complex material that gains strength over time. Having different properties at each length scale (from nano to macro), there is strong evidence that the properties and processes occurring at the small scale ultimately affect the engineering properties and performance of the bulk material. Therefore, if the fundamental mechanisms behind failure of cement can be better understood at small scale, rationally designed engineering solutions can be deployed to provide tougher materials for civil infrastructure, reducing consumption of natural resources and production of CO2.

 

The overall objective of this project was to quantitatively assess the quasi-brittle failure mechanisms at small scales using nanoindentation experiments with Focused Ion Beam (FIB) milled sample structures. The results can help develop a fundamental understanding of the failure behavior of cement paste at submicron length scales in support of rational design of tougher materials. The novel FIB milled sample preparation techniques were tailored and optimized to determine appropriate parameters for using on a heterogeneous multi- phase material like cement paste. To our best knowledge, this is the first study to fabricate and successfully test micron sized pillars on individual components of cement paste. It is also the first study to experimentally measure and report the individual compressive strength of different component phases. Our results confirmed that failure properties are repeatable within each phase but distinguishable between phases. Moreover, our experimental results showed that the compressive strength for individual components of cement paste is significantly higher as compared to that of the macroscopic paste.

 

Our research offers a novel perspective of studying microscopic failure of cementitious materials through an innovative approach which combines highly sophisticated sample preparation techniques, chemical analysis, mechanical characterization by nanoindentation equipment, state-of-the art microscopy and data analysis. We developed a robust testing protocol that can be applied for characterization of a wide range of quasi-brittle and heterogeneous materials such as sedimentary rocks and biological minerals. The outcomes of this research provided improved fundamental understanding of how cement paste fails at the small scale. It will lead to significant broader impacts in the study of failure of cementitious materials. Finally, the research supported the training of a graduate student in advanced experimental techniques.

 


Last Modified: 03/16/2017
Modified by: Mohammad Pour-Ghaz
